prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person who wrote the story is in the wrong. The situation is about a husband setting up his office in the bedroom, causing disruptions for the wife who has to take care of kids and work from home too.

First, I need to break down the key points. The husband works from home a few days a week, chose the bedroom over the basement because of the view. His job is mostly conference calls, so the wife has to keep the kids from disturbing him. This makes the top floor off-limits, affecting her ability to do chores, shower, take naps, etc. She suggested the basement which is quieter, but he refuses. She's working from home and handling most housework and kids. She told him she can't guarantee silence if he's in the bedroom, but he says she's the asshole for not being quiet. She's the one asking if she's in the wrong.

So, the question is whether the author (the wife) is wrong for not letting the husband have undisturbed work time in the bedroom. 

I need to consider both sides. The husband has the right to work without interruptions, but the wife has her own work and responsibilities. The basement is available and quieter, which would prevent the disruptions. He chose the bedroom despite the suggestion, which seems to be a choice that prioritizes his view over the wife's convenience. 

The wife is working from home and managing the household, which is a lot. If he had chosen the basement, the disruptions wouldn't happen. By choosing the bedroom, he's creating a situation where the wife can't do her tasks. So, maybe the husband is at fault here. 

But does the wife have a responsibility to keep things quiet even if he chose the bedroom? The user is asking if she's in the wrong. If the husband made a choice that leads to her being unable to do her work and chores, perhaps he's the one at fault. The wife is trying to balance everything and is being asked to make sacrifices she's not comfortable with. 

In terms of fairness, if there's a solution (basement) that would prevent the problem, but he refuses to take it, then the issue is on his side. The wife is just trying to set boundaries to manage her own responsibilities. So the answer would be B, the author is not in the wrong.
